articles.headline: G.E.’s Bid for Alstom Is Blessed by France
articles.snippet: The government of François Hollande backed G.E.’s offer to buy part of Alstom, the French industrial conglomerate, shutting out Siemens and Mitsubishi.
articles.abstract: The government of François Hollande backed G.E.’s offer to buy part of Alstom, the French industrial conglomerate, shutting out Siemens and Mitsubishi.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:28 p.m. |
articles.byline: By David Jolly and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Health Insurers Pressing Down on Drug Prices
articles.snippet: More health prescription plans are refusing to cover certain drugs unless the companies charge less for them.
articles.abstract: More health prescription plans are refusing to cover certain drugs unless the companies charge less for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: In dealing with health plans, drug companies are facing a new imperative — bargain or be banned.

articles.headline: A Central American Mouse Roars
articles.snippet: Using a high-pressure defensive style, Costa Rica, ranked 34th in the world, stunned Italy and secured a place in the second round of the World Cup.
articles.abstract: Using a high-pressure defensive style, Costa Rica, ranked 34th in the world, stunned Italy and secured a place in the second round of the World Cup.
articles.lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — There was less than 20 minutes left to play here on Friday when a bundle of three balloons — red, white and green, the colors of Italy’s flag — floated down from the stands and onto the field.

articles.headline: Booksellers Score Some Points in Amazon’s Spat With Hachette
articles.snippet: Publishers may lose the skirmish with Amazon, but the fight hasn’t gone unnoticed by independent bookstores, or book buyers.
articles.abstract: Publishers may lose the skirmish with Amazon, but the fight hasn’t gone unnoticed by independent bookstores, or book buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert Sindelar, the bearded, redheaded managing partner at the Seattle independent bookseller Third Place Books — definitely a David to Amazon’s Goliath — got the idea to take on Amazon while attending BookExpo America in New York a few weeks ago.

articles.headline: Deep in the Amazon, an Isolated Village Tunes In to the World Cup
articles.snippet: The fevered grip of the world’s largest sporting event can be felt even in some of the most isolated areas of the rain forest, where outsiders seldom visit.
articles.abstract: The fevered grip of the world’s largest sporting event can be felt even in some of the most isolated areas of the rain forest, where outsiders seldom visit.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAUS, Brazil — The PP Maués would not set sail for an hour, but its long and narrow decks were already crisscrossed with hammocks for an overnight trip down the Amazon.

articles.headline: Hi, I’m a Tablet. I’ll Be Your Waiter Tonight.
articles.snippet: Chains like Panera Bread and Chili’s are using apps and tablets to improve food preparation, ordering and payment, and to entertain customers.
articles.abstract: Chains like Panera Bread and Chili’s are using apps and tablets to improve food preparation, ordering and payment, and to entertain customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRAINTREE, Mass. — An idea came to Ronald M. Shaich, the chief executive of Panera Bread, as he was driving his children to school about four years ago: What if everyone could order lunch the way he did?

articles.headline: Presbyterians Vote to Divest Holdings to Pressure Israel
articles.snippet: The church voted at its general convention to divest from three companies that it says supply Israel with equipment used in the occupation of Palestinian territory.
articles.abstract: The church voted at its general convention to divest from three companies that it says supply Israel with equipment used in the occupation of Palestinian territory.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — After passionate debate over how best to help break the deadlock between Israel and the Palestinians, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) voted on Friday at its general convention to divest from three companies that it says supply Israel with equipment used in the occupation of Palestinian territory.

articles.headline: On Immigration, the Hard Lines Start to Blur
articles.snippet: Farmers Branch, Tex., was once a leader in passing laws intended to curb immigration, but those laws were struck down and people are adapting.
articles.abstract: Farmers Branch, Tex., was once a leader in passing laws intended to curb immigration, but those laws were struck down and people are adapting.
articles.lead_paragraph: FARMERS BRANCH, Tex. — Halfway through an evening of campaigning for mayor of this Dallas suburb, David Koch met a Colombian immigrant who had just moved in. “Well, welcome to the town,” he said, adding after friendly chatter: “Why did you pick Farmers Branch?”

articles.headline: Iraq Insurgents Reaping Wealth as They Advance
articles.snippet: Behind the image of savagery that the extremists of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria present lies a disciplined organization that employs social media and sophisticated financial strategies.
articles.abstract: Behind the image of savagery that the extremists of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria present lies a disciplined organization that employs social media and sophisticated financial strategies.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — When Qaeda-style insurgents overran the northern city of Mosul, among the war booty they seized were what they claimed were five American-made helicopters.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Held Captive by Flawed Credit Reports
articles.snippet: Errors in credit reports continue, consumers and their lawyers say, making them wonder if the reporting companies view the penalties they pay as just a cost of doing business.
articles.abstract: Errors in credit reports continue, consumers and their lawyers say, making them wonder if the reporting companies view the penalties they pay as just a cost of doing business.
articles.lead_paragraph: When companies are found to have violated the law and harmed consumers, they typically pay a penalty to regulators and agree to reform their practices.

articles.headline: Yahoo Wants You to Linger (on the Ads, Too)
articles.snippet: With a huge audience but declining ad revenue, the company is pinning its revival on a constellation of sites, where news and advertising intertwine.
articles.abstract: With a huge audience but declining ad revenue, the company is pinning its revival on a constellation of sites, where news and advertising intertwine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four editors were deep in debate at Yahoo Food’s offices in Manhattan: Would Yahoo visitors click on a feature about foods of the ancient Silk Road, or would they prefer a guide to cheese fries and other snacks that go well with ranch dressing for the Final Four basketball games?

articles.headline: A Job Seeker’s Desperate Choice
articles.snippet: The story of Shanesha Taylor, a mother who had a job interview but was unable to find child care, shows the harsh realities of today’s economy.
articles.abstract: The story of Shanesha Taylor, a mother who had a job interview but was unable to find child care, shows the harsh realities of today’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the morning of March 20, Shanesha Taylor had a job interview. It was for a good job, one that could support her three children, unlike the many positions she’d applied for that paid only $10 an hour. The interview, at an insurance agency in Scottsdale, Ariz., went well. “Walking out of the office, you know that little skip thing people do?” she said, clicking her heels together in a corny expression of glee. “I wanted to do that.”

articles.headline: Unblinking Eyes Track Employees
articles.snippet: Abundant data, smart software and cheap sensors are beginning to make it possible to measure and monitor employees as never before.
articles.abstract: Abundant data, smart software and cheap sensors are beginning to make it possible to measure and monitor employees as never before.
articles.lead_paragraph: A digital Big Brother is coming to work, for better or worse.

articles.headline: The Anchor on an Evolving Team
articles.snippet: As Coach Jurgen Klinsmann reshaped the U.S. team, Tim Howard, the longtime goalkeeper, remained a steady hand and supportive teammate.
articles.abstract: As Coach Jurgen Klinsmann reshaped the U.S. team, Tim Howard, the longtime goalkeeper, remained a steady hand and supportive teammate.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Tim Howard did not always like what Jurgen Klinsmann was doing to Howard’s closest friends. He actually hated it. One by one, all of the veteran players on the United States national team had their moments with Klinsmann, the coach from Germany, who had made clear since the moment he was hired in 2011 that history and past performance meant nothing to him.

articles.headline: Rite of the Sitting Dead: Funeral Poses Mimic Life
articles.snippet: Funeral services in New Orleans and Puerto Rico pose the dead to play host at their own wakes, propped up in a familiar tableau.
articles.abstract: Funeral services in New Orleans and Puerto Rico pose the dead to play host at their own wakes, propped up in a familiar tableau.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — All last week, people were calling Louis Charbonnet to find out how they might avoid lying down at their funerals. Funeral directors have called; so have people with their own requests, such as the woman who wanted to be seen for the last time standing over her cooking pot.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Answering a Cleric’s Call, Iraqi Shiites Take Up Arms
articles.snippet: Large sections of Baghdad and southern Iraq’s Shiite heartland have been swept up in a mass mobilization, energized by a fatwa urging able-bodied Iraqis to take up arms against Sunni extremists.
articles.abstract: Large sections of Baghdad and southern Iraq’s Shiite heartland have been swept up in a mass mobilization, energized by a fatwa urging able-bodied Iraqis to take up arms against Sunni extremists.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The long lines of Shiite fighters began marching through the capital early Saturday morning. Some wore masks. One group had yellow and green suicide explosives, which they said were live, strapped to their chests.

articles.headline: Late Shock Interrupts U.S. Party
articles.snippet: The United States used goals by Jermaine Jones and Clint Dempsey to take a 2-1 lead, but a stoppage-time goal by Silvestre Varela gave Portugal a 2-2 tie in Manaus, Brazil, on Sunday.
articles.abstract: The United States used goals by Jermaine Jones and Clint Dempsey to take a 2-1 lead, but a stoppage-time goal by Silvestre Varela gave Portugal a 2-2 tie in Manaus, Brazil, on Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAUS, Brazil — The ball was barely past United States goalkeeper Tim Howard, and already he had put his hands to his head. On the bench, Jurgen Klinsmann spun away as if he had seen a ghost. Up the field, not far from where he lost the ball, Michael Bradley could only stare.

articles.headline: Quirky to Create a Smart-Home Products Company
articles.snippet: Quirky, a start-up, is setting up a separate company, Wink, whose main technology is software intended to help seamlessly connect all kinds of automated home devices.
articles.abstract: Quirky, a start-up, is setting up a separate company, Wink, whose main technology is software intended to help seamlessly connect all kinds of automated home devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: The repurposed red brick warehouse in Manhattan’s Chelsea neighborhood is a bustling hub of modern industrial activity. Skilled young workers are hunched over pristine machine tools and 3-D printers that churn out prototype products.

articles.headline: Fate of 3 Kidnapped Israelis Raises Tensions on Many Fronts
articles.snippet: A kidnapping highlights the huge gulf, political and psychological, between long-warring neighbors and is raising fears of a third intifada in the Palestinian territories.
articles.abstract: A kidnapping highlights the huge gulf, political and psychological, between long-warring neighbors and is raising fears of a third intifada in the Palestinian territories.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Three Israeli teenagers kidnapped from the West Bank have been missing for more than 10 days now, their names — Naftali, Gilad, Eyal — becoming staples of synagogue prayers and cafe chatter across this tiny country. Four Palestinians, one of them 15, have been killed by Israeli troops, their photos hoisted at mass funerals as martyrs in the liberation struggle.

articles.headline: Despite a Hex, Ronaldo Works Magic
articles.snippet: A witch doctor from Ghana put a curse on the knees of Cristiano Ronaldo, Portugal’s star player in the World Cup. But apparently it’s not working very well.
articles.abstract: A witch doctor from Ghana put a curse on the knees of Cristiano Ronaldo, Portugal’s star player in the World Cup. But apparently it’s not working very well.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAUS, Brazil — The World Cup arrives every four years, and without fail it brings a good and possibly even true story about a witch doctor.

articles.headline: Iraq’s Military Seen as Unlikely to Turn the Tide
articles.snippet: Recent assessments by Western officials and military experts indicate that about a quarter of Iraq’s military forces are “combat ineffective.”
articles.abstract: Recent assessments by Western officials and military experts indicate that about a quarter of Iraq’s military forces are “combat ineffective.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — As Iraqi Army forces try to rally on the outskirts of Baghdad after two weeks of retreat, it has become increasingly clear to Western officials that the army will continue to suffer losses in its fight with Sunni militants and will not soon retake the ground it has ceded.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Relief Over U.S. Exit From Iraq Fades as Reality Overtakes Hope
articles.snippet: President Obama, who thought he had set Iraq on a stable course without American help, has now determined that American diplomacy and power are critical to saving it.
articles.abstract: President Obama, who thought he had set Iraq on a stable course without American help, has now determined that American diplomacy and power are critical to saving it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Standing in Al Faw palace in Baghdad, surrounded by an artificial lake and the ragged remnants of eight years of war, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. felt a surge of emotion on that day in December 2011.

articles.headline: Vice Has Many Media Giants Salivating, but Its Terms Will Be Rich
articles.snippet: Disney, 21st Century Fox and Time Warner are all seeking a piece of Vice Media, and its young, coveted audience.
articles.abstract: Disney, 21st Century Fox and Time Warner are all seeking a piece of Vice Media, and its young, coveted audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: A black S.U.V. recently rolled through the streets of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and stopped in front of the converted warehouse that is the global headquarters of Vice Media. Out of the vehicle stepped the media mogul Rupert Murdoch.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Mahler and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: A Novel Lays Bare Media Ills
articles.snippet: At first glance, “The Last Magazine: A Novel” by Michael Hastings would appear to lack relevance in the current media age, but even from the grave Mr. Hastings has demonstrated anew an ability to reframe the debate.
articles.abstract: At first glance, “The Last Magazine: A Novel” by Michael Hastings would appear to lack relevance in the current media age, but even from the grave Mr. Hastings has demonstrated anew an ability to reframe the debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first glance, “The Last Magazine: A Novel” by Michael Hastings would appear to lack relevance in the current media age. A fictional account of life inside a failed magazine — Newsweek — in a dying industry — print — written by a now-dead journalist, the book seems very much beside the point. And the march of history aside, does the world need another roman à clef from inside the world of Manhattan media, whose bottomless interest in itself is not generally shared by the public?

articles.headline: G.M. Prepares to Count Cost of Suffering
articles.snippet: The automaker is nearly ready to begin compensating those left injured by the defective ignition switches that led to the recall of 2.6 million vehicles.
articles.abstract: The automaker is nearly ready to begin compensating those left injured by the defective ignition switches that led to the recall of 2.6 million vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mykia Jordan has no memory of the car accident that put her in a coma for three weeks, left a large scar across her jaw and caused the limp that forces her to walk with a cane at 23.
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout, Bill Vlasic, Danielle Ivory and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: An Employee Dies, and the Company Collects the Insurance
articles.snippet: Many companies insure their employees’ lives with themselves as beneficiaries, a practice some deride as immoral. But companies say the policies, for which they get tax breaks, help them bolster pensions and health care.
articles.abstract: Many companies insure their employees’ lives with themselves as beneficiaries, a practice some deride as immoral. But companies say the policies, for which they get tax breaks, help them bolster pensions and health care.
articles.lead_paragraph: Employees at The Orange County Register received an unsettling email from corporate headquarters this year. The owner of the newspaper, Freedom Communications, was writing to request workers’ consent to take out life insurance policies on them.

articles.headline: Egypt Convicts 3 Journalists; U.S. Is Critical
articles.snippet: Prosecutors had accused the journalists of conspiring with the Muslim Brotherhood to broadcast false reports of civil strife in order to bring down the government.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors had accused the journalists of conspiring with the Muslim Brotherhood to broadcast false reports of civil strife in order to bring down the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry came to Egypt this weekend to renew its “important partnership” with Washington and to offer its new president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, assurance of the swift restoration of military aid.

articles.headline: Now the Air Bags Are Faulty, Too
articles.snippet: The expanded recall covers a total of almost three million cars worldwide whose air bags could rupture and injure passengers.
articles.abstract: The expanded recall covers a total of almost three million cars worldwide whose air bags could rupture and injure passengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the most critical safety components in cars, the air bag, is rapidly becoming a central concern of automakers and regulators.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Christopher Jensen

articles.headline: Iraqi Insurgents Secure Control of Border Posts
articles.snippet: The seizing of the crossing raised the specter of the insurgency’s becoming a menace not just to Iraq and Syria, but also to Jordan and Saudi Arabia.
articles.abstract: The seizing of the crossing raised the specter of the insurgency’s becoming a menace not just to Iraq and Syria, but also to Jordan and Saudi Arabia.
articles.lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — The Sunni militant extremists who have seized a broad area of Iraq extended their control on Monday to the country’s entire western frontier, having secured nearly all official border crossings with Syria and the only one with Jordan, giving them the semblance of the new independent state that they say they intend to create in the region.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Justices Uphold Emission Limits on Big Industry
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court largely upheld the Environmental Protection Agency’s ability to regulate emissions from stationary sources. Justice Antonin Scalia said the agency got “almost everything it wanted.”
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court largely upheld the Environmental Protection Agency’s ability to regulate emissions from stationary sources. Justice Antonin Scalia said the agency got “almost everything it wanted.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a big win for environmentalists, the Supreme Court on Monday effectively endorsed the Obama administration’s efforts to regulate greenhouse gas emissions from sources like power plants, even as it criticized what it called the administration’s overreaching.
